subject: Made provision for glance service to use Launcher

values.-1: This patch needs further work before it can be merged
values.+1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

Patch Set 2: -Workflow

Hi All,

In this patch, as per discussion with Mark we have made the provision of processing SIGHUP and SIGTERM signals separately by writing new GlanceProcessLauncher class extending from ProcessLauncher class of oslo-incubator service module.

Thank you!!

Patch Set 2:

I don't think I'm seeing the expected behaviour when testing this patch.

If I start up a server (with this patch):

$ .tox/py27/bin/python -m glance.cmd.api --config-file /etc/glance/glance-api.conf

where glance-api.conf is a typical devstack config file (http://paste.openstack.org/show/104228/).

And I perform a long lived operation:


$ time glance image-download af72936f-6f39-46c0-853d-8d8741689ed0 > /dev/null

real	0m6.063s
user	0m3.760s
sys	0m1.036s

it completes ok. (So far so good).

If I find the parent pid ( 32113)

$ ps auwx|grep glance-api|grep -v grep
ubuntu   32113  5.4  0.4 155112 65652 pts/3    S+   13:27   0:02 .tox/py27/bin/python -m glance.cmd.api --config-file /etc/glance/glance-api.conf
ubuntu   32121  3.5  0.4 158820 67292 pts/3    S+   13:27   0:01 .tox/py27/bin/python -m glance.cmd.api --config-file /etc/glance/glance-api.conf

and restart the download, and send a HUP:

$ kill -HUP 32113

Then the download aborts straight away:

$ time glance image-download af72936f-6f39-46c0-853d-8d8741689ed0 > /dev/null
[Errno 32] Corrupt image download. Checksum was a3f562aeb4ed5c817ac3c7657fe542de expected 3e11f0eba713998542850e8b2bed67b0

real	0m1.839s
user	0m0.800s
sys	0m0.220s


according to the commit message I would have expected this to complete.

I have a separate query on the expected behaviour in another scenario...

What is the expected behaviour in the following (different) scenario:

1) a download (download1) is started
2) a KILL -HUP is sent to the glance-api parent process
3) a second download (download2) is started
4) download1 completes

should download2 complete (if so, then if new requests keep coming in the service may never restart)? or should it not have been allowed to start (in which case the service is offline on this node for the period that the in-flight requests take to complete)?

Really I'm wondering if we need to behave in the same way as swift, ie:

http://docs.openstack.org/developer/swift/admin_guide.html#swift-orphans

Patch Set 2:

Hi Stuart,

Thank you for testing the patch.

Are you running glance-api in daemon mode?

I have done the testing and used following steps:

1. returned True from glance/openstack/common/service.py #82 (assuming that glance-api is running as daemon)

2. Started glance-api service using cd /opt/stack/glance; /usr/local/bin/glance-api --config-file=/etc/glance/glance-api.conf

3. Started download and sent HUP signal to parent process

4. SIGHUP signal received and processed

5. Download completed successfully.

6. Glance-api Service restarted

Please correct me, if I am heading in wrong way.

Thank you!!!

Patch Set 2:

Hi Stuart,

1) a download (download1) is started
2) a KILL -HUP is sent to the glance-api parent process
3) a second download (download2) is started
4) download1 completes


In this scenario, download1 will complete before restarting the glance-api server and after glance-service gets restarted the download2 will get processed.

Patch Set 2:

> In this scenario, download1 will complete before restarting  the glance-api server and after glance-service gets restarted the download2 will get processed.

Can you explain how that will work?

For example: imagine at the start we have a child process 'C1' and a parent process 'P1'.
'C1' is handling the 'download1' request.
Then, we send a SIGHUP to P1.
Now while download1 is completing, and after we've sent the SIGHUP, we start download2 (which will be accepted eg by C1).
Then download1 completes and the service restarts while download2 is in-flight.

We now have a new parent process P2 and a new child process C2. Neither of which will know anything about 'download2'. So ... how do you see 'download2' completing?

Have you looked at what swift do in this case?

http://docs.openstack.org/developer/swift/admin_guide.html#swift-orphans

Patch Set 2:

Hi Stuart,

In current scenario we are not closing the original server socket, we are closing the duplicate socket.
Server socket will hold the connection until its time out from client side.

IMO, this behaviour is good in end-user's point of view, as user will not get error immediately.
It will wait until the requests time out and before this request time out completes, if SIGHUP signal processing is complete and service gets restarted completely then this request will get processed immediately.

This is what we feel good for the end-user, but we will like to hear the opinion of the community.

Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1

Marking as '-1' for now; as per IRC chat the commit message should be updated to give a better description of what happens when a SIGHUP is received (reload of some config file parameters, no reload of others).
Uploaded patch set 3.
Uploaded patch set 4.

Patch Set 4: Code-Review-1

(1 comment)

I'm not sure why so much code from openstack.common.service was cut and pasted?

Patch Set 4:

Brian: Presently, oslo-incubator doesn't send signal information (wait method) to the WSGIService which is needed in order to decide whether to process all the running request before restarting the service. 
As per Mark, there is no need to wait for all running requests to complete in case SIGTERM signal is sent.

To address this issue, we simply cannot change oslo-incubator at this last moment and use it in glance as it will impact all other OpenStack services using this service framework.

I have plan to submit a blueprint to make these changes to the oslo-incubator for K release.
Uploaded patch set 5.

Patch Set 5:

Mark, Brian:
We have added docstrings and also extended classes Services and Launcher from oslo-incubator to minimize cut and paste code as much as possible in the patch set 5.
Patch Set 5: Code-Review+2

Patch Set 6:

Hi All,

I have observed that Jenkins was failing intermittently for unit test glance.tests.unit.v1.test_api.TestGlanceAPI.test_add_copy_from_image_authorized_upload_image_authorized

I have tried to dig in and found that in this test copy-from location is used as 'http://glance.com/i.ovf'
(https://github.com/openstack/glance/blob/master/glance/tests/unit/v1/test_api.py#L896)

IMO, at above url no server is running on 80 port and because of this its raising 400 NotFound error form get_size() method of glance.store.http.Store class.
(https://github.com/openstack/glance/blob/master/glance/store/http.py#L148)

I have made change in the test case [1] to mock the get_size method as mentioned below which will always returns 0 size to ensure this test case will always get passed.

[1] http://paste.openstack.org/show/105111/

By making above change, its ensured that the test case will be passed every time.

So, should I include this change in the current patch?
Please let me know your opinion on the same.

Patch Set 6: Workflow-1

Hi Stuart,

Regarding functionality test, I have tested this patch in two ways:

1. Enabled SSL and checked requests are processed by the Api service before and after SIGHUP signal

2. Created a python script file which will send a request to server and send SIGHUP signal after every 5 minutes.
I have tested above script for 1 hour and confirmed every request has been processed successfully.

3. I have also ensured reloading of the parameters like filesystem_store_datadir, filesystem_store_datadirs are working effectively after sending the SIGHUP signal.

Please let me know your concerns about the functionality behavior, and I will try to address them ASAP.
Patch Set 6: -Workflow

Patch Set 6: Code-Review-1

Copying here the same response I sent to the mailing list:
"In principle I like the idea and concept, a lot. In practice I don’t think glance code is ready in a state that we could say SIGHUP reloads our configs. Even more my concern is that based on the behavior seen some config options gets picked up and some does not.

As long as we do not have definite list documented what options gets updated on the fly and what is the actual behavior at the point when new config is picked up (lets say we have some locks in place and locking folder gets updated, what happens?) I don’t think we should be taking this functionality in. Even the current behavior is fundamentally broken, at least it’s broken in a way that it is consistent and the behavior is known.
"

Patch Set 6:

(3 comments)

Hi Stuart,

Please see the inline replies for your comments.

Thank You!!

Patch Set 6:

Hi Erno:

I agree that we must document what all config parameters will be reloaded after SIGHUP signal is processed, that's the reason why we have added DocImpact tag to this patch. We will test what parameters are reloaded and report them to the Doc team.

Our use case: We want to use SIGHUP signal to reload filesystem store related config parameters namely "filesystem_store_datadir" and "filesystem_store_datadirs" which are very crucial in the production environment especially for people using NFS. In case, the  filesystem is approaching at full capacity, administrator can add more storage and configured it via the above parameters which will be taken into effect upon sending SIGHUP signal.
Secondly, most of the OpenStack services uses service framework and it does handle reloading of configuration files via SIGHUP signal which glance cannot without this patch.

Patch Set 6:

Also related, if I do

 $ nc localhost 9292

prior to the SIGHUP

then no requests sent after the SIGHUP are processed by the server (until the nc process is killed). The connection from the nc process can be thought of as an unauthenticated client connection.
Uploaded patch set 7.

Patch Set 7:

Hi All,

All issues given on patch set #6 has been addressed.

Thank You

Patch Set 7: Code-Review-1

My reservations about this change are starting to pile up:

1) I'm not really sure the SIGHUP vs SIGTERM way of handling client connections is correct. Maybe there should be a configuration option that determines how client connections are handled, and maybe there should be some sort of timeout for waiting for client connections to complete


2) Its quite unpleasant that the way of reloading configs does not apply across all configuration settings. That is going to be really confusing for anyone trying to run the code. The "implicit" feeling nature of how reconfiguration works with oslo process launcher and oslo-config seems like a bad model.


3) We're down to the wire on the j3 release, and this work is feeling rushed. I would rather ensure more stability for other consumers of glance.

Patch Set 7:

Mark:
>>1) I'm not really sure the SIGHUP vs SIGTERM way of handling client connections is correct. Maybe there should be a configuration option that determines >>how client connections are handled, and maybe there should be some sort of timeout for waiting for client connections to complete
We can add "complete_requests_signals" parameter option in which operator can configure for what signals it should wait for the running requests to complete. If none is configured, then it that case it won't do anything and even it won't reload the configuration files in case of SIGHUP signal is sent (since we have subclassed Launcher and signo is sent to the restart method, we can skip reloading configuration files too).

Possible options:
complete_requests_signals = [1, 15]
Default will be None.

>>2) Its quite unpleasant that the way of reloading configs does not apply across all configuration settings. That is going to be really confusing for anyone >>trying to run the code. The "implicit" feeling nature of how reconfiguration works with oslo process launcher and oslo-config seems like a bad model.

We will test what configuration parameters are reloaded and report it to the Doc  team. Is it ok?

>>3) We're down to the wire on the j3 release, and this work is feeling rushed. I would rather ensure more stability for other consumers of glance.
OpenStack service framework is widely used by other projects, it's matured and we have throughly tested this patch to ensure that it doesn't break.

Patch Set 7: Verified+1

Patch Set 8: Code-Review-2

Hi Abishek,

For me there's a few issues with this approach.

For example, there is a race condition which means that in-flight requests are not guaranteed to succeed, plus the existing connections issue, plus the inability to change, eg workers.

I think being able to reload config/gracefully shutdown are both valuable things to have, so I'd like to work together to get the best behaviour possible here. 

I've put some thoughts here: 

https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/sighup-conf-reload 

I plan to put up a (prototype) patch in the next day or so, if you have time to take a look that would be much appreciated.

Thanks.
